Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Thermal Controls on Ecosystem Metabolism and Function: Scaling from Leaves to Canopies to Regions
Award.AbstractNarration:
Temperature exerts a primary environmental control on biological systems and processes at a range of scales in space and time. Its influence is fundamental, ranging from controls on the reaction rates of enzymes, ecosystem biogeochemical reactions, and large-scale distributions of plant and animal species. Temperature is also a fundamental characteristic of climate. Indeed, much of the concern about the impact of climate warming is motivated by the pervasive influence of temperature on organisms. Although most focus is usually on air temperature, the skin temperature of an organism, such as a plant, is actually more relevant in many cases. However, until now measurements of organismal temperature using thermal images taken from some distance away have been challenging because of sensor and computational limitations. This research project addresses this gap in understanding through three goals: (1) to assess the use of thermal imaging measurements for ecological and agricultural studies, such as monitoring the response of plant canopies to heat and drought stress; (2) to demonstrate the continuous deployment of robust thermal cameras for continuous canopy imaging for a range of ecosystems; and (3) to develop scaling algorithms to relate sparse measurements at individual canopy sites to the patterns observed at regional scales by sensors on aircraft and satellites. The work will combine temperature observations at a range of spatial resolutions with synthesis activities in an innovative manner. The results will enhance our understanding of how ecosystem structure and function are related to skin temperature patterns.

This project will introduce new technology and infrastructure for long-term thermal data collection that could have a large impact on our understanding of ecological functioning across multiple scales. It will combine the diverse interdisciplinary expertise of researchers at different stages in their careers in fields including plant physiology, remote sensing, biogeography, and statistics. Results will directly inform questions concerning the link between leaf temperatures and carbon assimilation by ecosystems and the response of natural and agricultural ecosystems to drought stress. It will address scaling of properties and processes related to temperature, as is required for predicting responses to climate change. Particular focus will be on the responses of ecosystems to drought and heat waves. More tangible outcomes will be advances in understanding of plant-temperature interactions in natural and managed ecosystems, as well as the establishment of canopy thermal imaging equipment at three long-term monitoring sites. Finally, this project will integrate research and teaching through the training of post-doctoral researchers, mentoring of undergraduate students, and development of laboratory modules based on the concepts and data generated by this project for undergraduate and graduate courses in geography, earth science, ecology, and environmental science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This was a 2 year Macrosystems "Proof of concept" grant that explored the use of thermal cameras to quantify and better understand terrestrial ecosystem function. Our efforts focused on methods development, field observation, and data analysis: our goals were to: 1) contribute to the development of field deployable optical and thermal imaging systems, 2) install and operate an imaging system at an eddy covariance tower in Southern California (Pinyon Flat), and 3) contribute to understanding how to use imagery to understand ecosystem function and conditions, such as Evapotranspiration and drought stress.

The most unique aspect of our approach was the development of integrated pan-tilt imaging systems, which have now gone through two generations.  The first generation, which we operated during summer 2013 to summer 2014, carried two cameras: a FLIR sc325 for thermal imaging and a JAI AD-80 for Red, Green, Blue and NIR imaging; these cameras were mounted on a pan-tilt that collected images at 27 pan and 9 tilt angles every hour during the day and 4 hours at night. The second generation, which we operated from summer 2014 to winter 2016, carried three cameras and four spectrometers: a FLIR sc315 for thermal imaging, a JAI AD-80 for Red, Green, Blue and NIR imaging, a Xenics Bobcat for SWIR imaging, and a 4-channel Ocean Optics spectrometer for detecting the Photochemical Reflectance Index (PRI) and Solar Induced Florescence (SIF); these instruments were mounted on a pan-tilt that was configured to collect images at 17 pan and 8 tilt angles every two hours during the day and 4 hours at night.

The attached figures show some of the data we collected.  The upper panel in the first image shows a false color mosaiced image of the site that is analogous a Landsat 5,4,3 image, with the SWIR band was mapped onto red, NIR onto green, and Red onto Blue.  This image illustrates how effectively this combination of bands can be used to classify and distinguish the surfaces at the site, with healthy photosynthetic vegetation showing up as green; sand and mineral soil as white or tan; and dead plant material as red. The lower panel shows the mosaiced thermal image that was collected at the same time as the upper panel.  Both the upper and middle panel are mosaics of 132 individual images (17 columns x 8 rows) that span a compass direction of 154o on the left edge (SSE) to 44o on the right (NNE) and from 82o below horizontal at the bottom to 2o above horizontal at the top.

The dataset we ultimately collected contains nearly ten thousand data collections. The second attached figure shows some of the time series that were subsequently extracted from the image dataset. All of the individual pixels in each mosaiced scene for each data collection, including those shown in the attached panels, were first categorized into 6 surface types (Photosynthetic Vegetation vs Mineral Soil vs NonPhotosynthetic Vegetation crossed with sunlit vs shaded), and then the statistics for each cover type were calculated for each mosaic, providing rich time series.

The lower attached panel distills millions of images and hundreds of billions of pixels - figuring out how to turn these image datasets into interpretable plots was one of the major challenges we faced.  The attached figures barely scratch the surface of what's available and possible, but nonetheless reveal a number of interesting patterns, such as the extraordinarily high summer temperatures for  sunlit PV and mineral surfaces (>60oC) and the divergent seasonal patterns between the classes.
